“Local journalism has been the policeman on the beat against misinformation,” @SenatorCantwell said in an interview Tuesday. “Keeping local news is too important to let these unfair market practices continue.” https://www.seattletimes.com/business/report-released-by-sen-maria-cantwell-slams-google-and-facebook-for-decimating-local-news-outlets/
“These unfair and abusive practices should be called out,” @SenatorCantwell said.
“Local news is an incredible engine for the creation of accurate information. We don’t want to lose that infrastructure.” -@SenatorCantwell

"The Democrats' report accuses the big platforms of unfairly using news content, taking news consumers’ data and diverting customers from local news websites, with little compensation." 
https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-donald-trump-virus-outbreak-media-social-media-98b9faa7bf2b8f73a34caa15acabb84b

“The @SenatorCantwell report says the Silicon Valley behemoths, who together control a majority of the U.S. digital advertising market, have engaged in 'unfair and abusive practices the FTC needs to enforce against.'” https://www.politico.com/newsletters/morning-tech/2020/10/27/cantwell-vs-tech-giants-791220

“Local news has been hijacked by a few large news aggregation platforms, most notably Google and Facebook, which have become the dominant players in online advertising.” -@SenatorCantwell 
https://www.reuters.com/article/usa-media-congress/us-agency-needs-new-powers-to-protect-local-news-industry-senator-idUSL1N2HI08Q

“They [local newspapers] are facing unfair practices,” @SenatorCantwell (D., Wash.), the ranking member on the committee, said in an interview. “We think Congress and the FTC should address those unfair practices.” https://www.wsj.com/articles/lawmakers-want-to-protect-local-newspapers-from-google-facebook-11603789201

It's been three years since Hurricane Harvey wreaked havoc on Texas, and we are still working with some communities in TX-27 to fully recover to this day. My bills would encourage a culture of savings by making it easier to be financially prepared. (6/6)

The coronavirus pandemic has caused disastrous economic impacts. Despite borrowing and spending trillions of federal dollars to provide direct financial assistance to the American people, many families still find themselves in precarious financial positions. (5/6)

With these new emergency savings accounts, individuals would be able to deposit and withdraw money from that account tax-free when they use it for qualified expenses, such as mortgages, rent, utilities, property taxes, child care, and health care. (4/6)
The second bill would provide small businesses with the ability to save up to 25% of their payroll expenses tax-free in an emergency savings account. (3/6)

The first bill would provide individual taxpayers with the ability to save up to $5,000 per year by making tax-free contributions to an emergency savings account. A married couple would be able to save up to $10,000. (2/6)

I recently introduced two bills: the Emergency Savings Account Act and the Small Business Emergency Savings Account Act to help Americans to better prepare for the future. (1/6)

We need to be making it easier for folks to get the care they need during this crisis. I've worked to increase coverage for children and families and to expand Medicaid in Alabama, and I'm going to keep fighting to protect our care.

Young people under 26 would no longer be able to get coverage on their parent's plans. Millions of seniors would have to pay more for prescription drugs while pharmaceutical companies would pay billions less in taxes every year.

If the ACA is overturned, at least 122,000 Alabamians will lose their health care in the middle of a pandemic. People with pre-existing conditions would be charged higher rates or have their health care coverage ended altogether.
This isn't an abstract threat. The Supreme Court will begin hearing arguments in the case on November 10th.

The administration and several states, including Alabama, are advocating to completely eliminate The Affordable Care Act. Instead of working to improve it, they're pursuing overturning the entire law in the highest court in the land in the middle of this pandemic.

Our bill addresses these problems by creating a national framework that will allow board members to operate w/o the threat of personal liability while still ensuring that the boards are responsive to state gov’t oversight, professional standards & the wellbeing of the public.

The SCOTUS decision & subsequent lawsuits could have a long-term corrosive effect on the maintenance of professional standards as state boards struggle to find qualified board members willing to risk personal liability & the costs of defending themselves in litigation.

These people, rendering an essential public service & maintaining occupational standards, are now being put at risk. Since the 2015 ruling, there have been dozens of lawsuits brought against individual board members seeking antitrust treble damages for board actions and rulings.

According to a comprehensive 2017 study, there are nearly 2,000 occupational licensing boards in America & 85% of them mandate that their board members must actively work in the regulated occupation in order to serve. https://www.californialawreview.org/print/1-foxes-at-the-henhouse/

In 2015, the Supreme Court ruled in North Carolina State Board of Dental Examiners v. FTC that “if a ‘controlling number’ of a board’s members are active participants in the business it regulates, they could be sued as antitrust violators.” https://www.latimes.com/business/hiltzik/la-fi-hiltzik-20150329-column.html

ICYMI: Proud to introduce legislation with @RepCicilline & @ConawayTX11 to protect people who serve on state occupational licensing boards. Our bipartisan bill would keep members of state boards from being sued individually for board actions: https://raskin.house.gov/media/press-releases/raskin-cicilline-conaway-introduce-legislation-reform-state-occupational

Si uno de sus familiares o seres queridos murió debido a COVID-19, puedes someter su nombre y una fotografía para honrar a esa persona en un altar de muertos dedicado a las víctimas de COVID.
Día de los Muertos is a Meso-American tradition observed on November 1 & 2 to honor the dead. The altar is typically decorated with bright marigold flowers, photos, and other items of remembrance.

If you've lost a loved one and wish to honor them, you can submit their name & picture to include in the altar. 

The deadline is this Thursday at 3 p.m. ➡️ click here: https://www.supervisornathanfletcher.com/content/d4/en/community/dia_de_los_muertos.html

The altar will remain up through Monday, November 2.

We've seen how COVID-19 disproportionately affects Latinos. In CA, Latinos make up nearly half of COVID deaths.

If you need more information for your state: https://howto.vote/
Arizona also has a bunch of ballot drop boxes. You can find the closest one to you and see a map of all your options here: https://www.azcleanelections.gov/how-to-vote/early-voting/vote-by-mail
If you’re in Georgia (yes, it’s a swing state!) you can find your nearest ballot drop box at https://gaballotdropbox.org - thanks @GeorgiaDemocrat!

In North Carolina, you can drop off your ballot at your county office, or at *any* early voting site. You can find a full list of both of those, and search for the closest one to you at https://vt.ncsbe.gov/OSSite/

Pennsylvania has an all Democratic executive branch, so no surprise they make dropping off your ballot super easy. There are multiple offices, drop boxes, and satellite voting offices, and all the information you need to find yours is here: https://www.votespa.com/Voting-in-PA/pages/drop-box.aspx

In Iowa it’s the same story. Your only option for dropping off an absentee ballot is at your county commissioner or auditor’s office. Many of these offices do have installed drop boxes in front of them so you don’t have to go inside. Find yours here: https://sos.iowa.gov/elections/auditors/auditorslist.html

In Ohio, Republicans have been fighting tooth and nail to limit where you can vote early and drop off your ballot. They’ve limited those locations to only your county election center. You can find yours here: https://www.ohiosos.gov/elections/voters/toolkit/early-voting/#map
In Michigan there are lots of places to drop your ballot. You can find the closest ballot drop off location with the Michigan Sec. of State: https://mvic.sos.state.mi.us/

But what if you aren’t lucky enough to live in Minnesota 😉? Don’t worry. Got you covered. In Wisconsin, cities and towns set their own locations, but typically are at your municipal clerk's office. 

You can find yours, and check your ballot status, at https://myvote.wi.gov/en-us/

In Minnesota, you can drop your ballot anywhere you can vote in-person. 

Some cities and towns have other locations, too. You can find those here: https://www.sos.state.mn.us/elections-voting/other-ways-to-vote/cities-and-towns-with-in-person-absentee-voting/

These days, it's hard to find issues that unite everybody. But Montanans have figured out something that brings us all together—the love we have for our public lands and our desire to keep our air and water clean. That's why the Montana Headwaters Legacy Act is so important.

The Montana Headwaters Legacy Act ensures our rivers in the Custer-Gallatin and the Helena-Lewis and Clark National Forests are protected from development that would impact their recreational, scenic, or fisheries values, and stay free-flowing for generations.

Proud to join folks on the banks of the Gallatin to introduce the Montana Headwaters Legacy Act, the largest Wild and Scenic designation in nearly 45 years. Together, we are protecting hundreds of miles of rivers across Montana from short-sighted special interests. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ElXWBJCWoAEXVam.jpg

Two years ago today, we witnessed the most deadly act of violence against the Jewish community in American history. I stand with Pittsburgh & Jewish communities across Pennsylvania & the U.S. to remember & honor the victims of the Tree of Life synagogue. These are their stories:
My thoughts and prayers are with the Wallace family and all of those who are grieving, the 30 police officers who were injured in the line of duty yesterday, and the people of West Philadelphia. /9
The unrest in Philadelphia overnight is demonstrative of a community in pain and asking for justice. I am listening, and I will continue to fight to reform our systems. /8

My bill will create a permanent review board to examine every violent interaction between law enforcement & people with disabilities, & also provide new resources for people in mental health crises as well as specific training for law enforcement to appropriately respond to them.

It is long past time to reform a system that has been broken for far too long and cost far too many lives. In the coming days, I will be introducing legislation to change how the police interact with people with disabilities and those experiencing a mental health crisis. /6

Walter Wallace Jr.’s life mattered. His death is a tragedy and another failure of our systems of policing and criminal justice. We have to change how police and law enforcement respond to these situations, and we can start by passing the Justice in Policing Act of 2020. /5

...rather than firing a dozen shots, especially when a victim may be in mental distress. There are no simple answers, but as long as people of color keep dying unnecessarily at the hands of police, we must keep searching for solutions and striving for systemic change. /4

Police officers have difficult, dangerous jobs that require quick decisions with long-term consequences. We must find ways to protect the safety of everyone involved in these critical situations and to de-escalate them... /3

I have spoken with Mayor Kenney and Police Commissioner Outlaw to express my concern about what I saw on video of Mr. Wallace’s last moments. There must be a swift and truly independent investigation into the circumstances surrounding Mr. Wallace’s death. /2

I am saddened and disturbed at the loss of another Black man, Walter Wallace Jr., at the hands of the police. My heart is with the Wallace family and the West Philadelphia community that Walter called home. /1

It is my duty to speak up on these fundamental questions of racial justice and policing and to take part in a process of true de-escalation. I am calling on Interim Macomb County Prosecutor Jean Cloud to drop the felony charges as an important first step in this process.
As a result of all of this, I’m concerned about tensions continuing to rise unnecessarily in Macomb County, just when we seemed to be heading towards more racial justice and understanding.
They continued even once the protestors returned to the sidewalk. That’s not de-escalation. They sought felony charges. That’s definitely not de-escalation.

The police turned out in force with riot gear to meet 100 peaceful protesters. That’s not de-escalation. They dealt with protestors with aggressive takedowns, using such force that a protestor ended up in the hospital with a concussion. That’s not de-escalation.

Unfortunately, what was documented about his department’s response to peaceful protests on October 24 in news coverage, photos, videos, and first-person accounts did not look like the result of de-escalation training, but purposeful escalation instead.

Instead of firing him, the township board decided to give Chief Shelide a brief suspension without pay and require him to go through cultural sensitivity and de-escalation training before he returned.
He also showed little remorse for his statements, saying they had been taken out of context and misunderstood.
This summer, Shelby Twp. Police Chief Robert Shelide published racist and disturbing statements on social media that would result in termination in most large companies, nonprofits and governments.

The County Sheriff, Sterling Heights and Clinton Twp. closed the biggest surface street in the county and made everyone feel welcome. That is why I am so disturbed to see recent developments in Shelby Township, where a peaceful demonstration was met with disproportionate force.

I’ve been inspired by the response to the national crisis of racial justice and policing in Macomb County. This summer, I marched alongside thousands of Macomb residents from all walks of life, mobilizing peacefully to seek change.

As the representative of much of Macomb County in Congress, I am calling on Interim Macomb Prosecutor Jean Cloud to drop felony charges against people who engaged in nonviolent demonstrations in Shelby Township this weekend.
